covered: Valid Request: Happy path and many valid query-parameter combinations are covered (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC18).
Empty Response: Empty-result scenarios when no accounts exist or none match are covered (TC04, TC05).
Pagination: Basic pagination behaviors are tested (offset and limit in TC02, TC03) including a large-volume request in TC15.
Query Parameters: Various valid and invalid query parameter cases are tested (accountWithBalance, accountWithBalanceAndCBA, audit values, invalid booleans/enums in TC02, TC07, TC08, TC14).
Authorization: Missing and invalid authentication token cases are covered (TC09, TC10).
Error Handling & Security: Malformed search keys, SQL injection, XSS, service errors, timeouts, and dependent-service failures are covered (TC06, TC11, TC12, TC13, TC16, TC19).
Performance / Concurrency: Large data volume and basic concurrency behaviour are addressed (TC15).
Regression & Compatibility: Empty searchKey regression and backward-compatibility scenario covered (TC17, TC18).
Accessibility: Response payload clarity for assistive tech is addressed (TC20).
gaps: Rate Limiting / Throttling: No explicit tests that trigger or assert rate-limit behavior or throttling responses (429). TC15 concurrency does not assert throttling behavior.
Caching Behavior / Headers: No tests assert caching-related headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or conditional GET handling.
Content-Type & Response Headers: Tests do not assert Content-Type or other response headers (e.g., charset, pagination link headers).
403 Forbidden: Authorization checks only cover 401; there are no scenarios for 403 (authenticated but unauthorized) if applicable.

Pagination edge cases & metadata: Missing tests for boundary cases (offset beyond result set, limit=0, extremely large limits beyond allowed max) and for pagination metadata (total count, next/prev links) if supported by API.
URL encoding / unicode handling: No explicit tests for encoded characters, spaces, or multi-byte/unicode search keys (e.g., "José", percent-encoded values).
Response schema/contract validation: No strict assertions on full Account object schema (required fields, field types, nullable behaviour) beyond presence/absence of balance/CBA/audit.
Consistency of error codes: Tests accept 400/422 for some security cases but do not assert a consistent error-mode or structured error body (code/message/fields).
Rate-of-change / data-consistency under concurrent updates: No tests covering consistency when account data is changing while searching (stale reads, snapshot behavior).
recommendations: Add explicit rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts of requests and assert 429 responses or defined throttling behavior and headers (Retry-After).
Add caching and conditional-request tests: assert presence and semantics of ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified headers and behavior for If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since.
Assert response headers and content-type: include checks for Content-Type: application/json and any pagination headers (Link, X-Total-Count) if applicable.
Add pagination boundary tests: offset beyond end, limit=0, limit greater than maximum allowed, and validate behavior and error codes or truncation rules.
Add URL-encoding and unicode tests for searchKey: spaces, percent-encoded characters, and international characters to ensure correct handling.
Introduce JSON schema / contract tests for Account objects: validate required fields, field types, and nullability for all combinations of query parameters (balance/CBA/audit).
Define and enforce consistent error responses: add tests that assert structured error bodies (error code, message, details) and consistent status codes (400 vs 422) for validation/security errors.
Add authorization scope tests: include scenarios that assert 403 for authenticated but unauthorized access if the API supports role-based restrictions.
Add tests for data-consistency under concurrent modifications: run searches while accounts are created/updated/deleted to validate stability/atomicity expectations.

Extend performance tests: increase concurrency and run sustained load tests, assert SLOs (response time percentiles) and resource utilization; include tests that intentionally exceed limits to observe failure modes.
